Fractal characteristics of nano-pores in the Lower Silurian Longmaxi shales from the Upper Yangtze Platform, south China

a b s t r a c t
To better understand the fractal characteristics of nano-pore structure and their effects on methane adsorption in marine shales, we have conducted ultra-low pressure nitrogen adsorption, methane adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), total organic carbon (TOC), and vitrinite reflectance for eleven shale samples of the Lower Silurian Longmaxi Formation from the Upper Yangtze Platform, south China. Two fractal dimensions D1 and D2 (at relative pressures of 0e0.5 and 0.5e1, respectively) were obtained using the fractal FrenkeleHalseyeHill (FHH) method based on low-pressure nitrogen adsorption isotherms. The relationships among composition of the Longmaxi shale (TOC, clay minerals, brittle minerals), the pore structure parameters (i.e. average pore diameter, surface area, pore volume), and the fractal dimensions were investigated. The results show that the Longmaxi shale possesses fractal geometries with fractal dimension D1 values ranging from 2.3542 to 2.4715 and fractal dimension D2 values ranging from 2.5818 to 2.7497. The good positive correlation between fractal dimensions D1 and the BET surface area and the strongly negative relationship between fractal dimensions D2 and the average pore diameter indicate that D1 can adequately characterize pore surface fractal dimension, while D2 represents the pore structure fractal dimension. Organic matter has a positive influence on the BET surface area and the BJH pore volume and a negative effect on the average pore diameter. The BJH pore volume and the average pore diameter have a positive relationship trend with the clay minerals content, whereas a negative linear trend with the brittle minerals content. The mineralogical compositions and TOC of the Longmaxi shale have different impacts on the pore structures, which in turn exert different effects on the fractal dimensions D1 and D2. Both the fractal dimensions D1 and D2 have positive effects on the Langmuir volume of methane adsorption. However, the fractal dimensions D1 and D2 have opposite influence on the Langmuir pressures of methane adsorption. Thus the fractal dimensions can well be used to evaluate gas shale reservoir and shale gas accumulation in south China.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recent advances in horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing have made it technically and economically feasible to producing natural gas from shale formations (Rexer et al., 2013). Total dry natural gas production in the United States increased by 35% from 2005 to 2013, which resulted largely from the development of shale
etroleum Resources and Pro49, China.
gas resources (EIA, 2015). Outside of North America, China also achieved great success in shale gas production which increases from 25 106 m3 in 2012 to 200 106 m3 in 2013 (Zhang et al., 2012a,b). Natural gas storage in shale differs significantly from conventional gas reservoirs and may be composed of free compressed gas, adsorption gas and dissolved gas (Curtis, 2002; Gasparik et al., 2014). Organic shale typically contains a complicated pore system with various pore types, multiple pore geometries and wide pore size distributions (Loucks et al., 2012; Clarkson et al., 2013). In addition, the pore size distribution of shale may lead to different gas accumulation mechanisms and gas transition
mechanisms (Sondergeld et al., 2007;Wang et al., 2015a). Generally speaking, macropores would provide space for free gas, whereas mesopores or micropores could offer larger surface areas and higher adsorption energy for gas adsorption (Bu et al., 2015). Continuum and no slip flow are dominant in macropores and megapores but gas slippage and diffusion are dominant in micropores and mesopores (Sondergeld et al., 2007). Therefore, characterizing the pore structure is critical to understand shale gas storage and flow mechanisms.
Three groups of experimental techniques could be used to characterize shale pore structure (Wang et al., 2015a): microscopic observation (e.g., scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy) (Loucks et al., 2009, 2012; Chalmers et al., 2012; Klaver et al., 2012), radiation detection (e.g., small or ultrasmall angle neutron scattering, nuclear magnetic resonance) (Clarkson et al., 2013; Bahadur et al., 2014; Sigal, 2015; Meng et al., 2015), and fluid invasion (e.g., gas physisorption, mercury intrusion, helium pycnometry) (Ross and Bustin, 2009; Chalmers et al., 2012; Clarkson et al., 2013; Tian et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2014). Among these, low-pressure nitrogen adsorption analysis has been proven to be an effective method in characterizing pore structures in shales (Clarkson et al., 2013; Labani et al., 2013; Tian et al., 2013), and N2 adsorption data indicate that the porous materials have fractal geometries (Yao et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2014). However, there are relatively few case studies on the fractal characterization of marine shales and its effect on methane adsorption properties.
In this pater, we carried out fractal analyses on the Lower Silurian Longmaxi marine shale from the Upper Yangtze Platform in south China. Using the fractal FrenkeleHalseyeHill (FHH) method and data measured from ultra-low pressure nitrogen adsorption isotherms, we obtained fractal dimension values of the pore structure and surface, respectively. Then the relationships between TOC, minerals content, pore structure parameters and fractal dimensions were documented. And the role of fractal dimensions in methane adsorption properties of marine shales was also discussed. The results could be helpful to understand the nano pore characterization in the Longmaxi marine shale and to evaluate the shale gas accumulation in south China.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and experimental methods
sections.text:
The Upper Yangtze Platform is located in the western portion of
Fig. 1. Map showing the location of the sample wells (B) on the edge of the so
the Yangtze Platform, south China (Fig. 1A). The Lower Silurian shale, widely developed in the Upper Yangtze Platform has recently been selected as the main target for shale gas exploration and development (Dong et al., 2012; Guo and Zhang, 2014; Dai et al., 2014; Luo et al., 2016). A total of 11 samples from the Lower Silurian Longmaxi marine shale were collected from four wells (YC4, YC6, YC7 and YC8) in the Upper Yangtze Platform on the southeastern edge of Sichuan Basin, south China (Fig. 1B). The Longmaxi Formation is composed mainly of marine shales and mudstones, which can be subdivided into two sections based on the lithology. The lower section of the Longmaxi Formation is composed mainly of arenaceous shale, carbonaceous shale and graptolitic shale interbedded with bioclastic limestone. The upper section is comprised mainly of shale and arenaceous shale interbedded with siltstone and marlstone (Dai et al., 2014). High TOC sections mainly developed in the bottom part of the Longmaxi Formation. The Longmaxi shale is currently highly over-matured, generating mainly dry gas and secondary oil cracked gas (Tan et al., 2015). More detailed information on the geological and geochemical characteristics of the shale gas in the Longmaxi Formation can be obtained from Dai et al., (2014).
The shale samples were crushed and sieved into grains of 80e100mesh size for ultra-low pressure nitrogen adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and total organic carbon (TOC) measurement. The TOC content was determined by a Leco CS230 carbon/sulfur analyzer. Samples were crushed to a powder with grain size less than 100 mesh, and then 1 g of the shale samples, in a porous crucible, were treated using hydrochloric acid to remove carbonates. After 2 h the samples were washed out using distilled water. After the water had drained from the crucible, the crucible and sample were dried overnight at 70 C. The total organic carbon content was then measured. Because no vitrinite occurs in rocks earlier than Devonian due to the absent of higher land plants, we measured the reflection of solid bitumen reflection (Rb). Then we converted the reflection of solid bitumen reflection (Rb) to equivalent vitrinite reflectance (Ro*) based on the following linear regression: Ro* ¼ 0.618Rbþ4 (Jacob, 1985).
Bulk mineralogical compositions were determined from the Xray diffraction patterns measured on a Bruker D8 DISCOVER diffractometer using Co Ka-radiation produced at 45 kV and 35mA. Crushed samples were mixed with ethanol, hand ground and then smear mounted on glass slides for X-ray diffraction analysis. During
utheastern Sichuan Basin in the Upper Yangtze Platform, south China (A).
the measurement, the sample was illuminated through a fixed divergence slit (1.8 mm, 1.45 ), a graphite monochromator, and 58 mm, 0.3 mm spacing Soller slits. The diffracted beam was measured with a scintillation detector with counting time of 20 s for each step of 0.02 2q. Diffractograms were recorded from 2 to 76 2q. Quantitative phase analysis was performed by Rietveld refinement, with customized clay mineral structure models (Ufer et al., 2008). All reported mineral compositions related to the crystalline content of the analyzed samples.
Ultra-low pressure N2 adsorption analyses were performed at 196 C and relative pressure ranged between 10 7 and 0.995 using a Quantachrome® Autosorb-iQ2-MP apparatus at School of Petrochemical Engineering in Changzhou University. Because the N2 diffusion velocity is extremely low in microporous materials under ultra-low pressure, the equilibration time was set to 10 min for the threshold of relative pressure of 10 6, decreased to 8min for relative pressure between 10 6 and 10 5, and then gradually decreased to 2 min for a relative pressure higher than 0.01. The pressure tolerance was set at 0.1 mmHg. Detailed information can be obtained from Wang and Ju (2015). Both adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured to investigate the hysteresis types. Results include the pore surface area, pore volumes and average pore diameter. The pore surface area is calculated from the BET (Brunauer Emmett Teller) equation (Brunauer et al., 1938). The pore volume of the shale samples were determined using the Barrett, Johner and Halenda (BJH) method for adsorption between relative pressure ranges of 0.06 and 0.99 (Barrett et al., 1951). The average pore diameters were obtained using the ratio between the total amount of nitrogen adsorbed and the surface area assuming cylindrical pore geometry (Labani et al., 2013).
High-pressuremethane adsorption isothermsweremeasured at a consistent temperature of 40 C and up to a pressure of 12 MPa using a FY-KT 1000 isothermal adsorption apparatus adopting GB/T 19560-2004 (Chinese National Standard) testing standard. The shale samples were crushed and sieved to less than 60 mesh particle size. Powdered samples were dried for 24 h at 105 C before the methane adsorption experiments. The detailed methane adsorption experimental procedure was described in detail by Ji et al. (2014). The measured adsorption data were parametrized using Langmuir function, and the analytical results include Langmuir volume and Langmuir pressure (Langmuir, 1918).

sections.heading: 3.1. Mineralogy and geochemistry
sections.text:
Detailed geochemical and mineralogical characteristics of the
Longmaxi shale samples are presented in Table 1. The equivalent vitrinite reflectance values of theses samples are between 1.93% and 2.78%. This indicates a high maturity level. The TOC contents range from 0.45 wt % to 4.13 wt %. As shown in Table 1, high TOC section is developed at the bottom part of the Longmaxi Formation. The XRD analysis results of the Longmaxi shale show a wide range of mineralogical compositions which are dominated by quartz and clays. The clay contents are between 21% and 58% with an average of 38.9%. The quartz contents range from 29% to 57% with a mean value of 37.5%. In addition, the mineral composition contains moderate amount of feldspar (6e21%) and carbonates (0e15%), and low abundance of pyrite (1e5%). For all of the Longmaxi shale samples the dominant clay minerals are illite (10e28%) and mixed layer illite/smectite (8e24%) with some chlorite (3e13%).

sections.heading: 3.2. CH4 adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
Methane adsorption isotherms of eight Longmaxi shale samples were obtained at 40 C and pressure up to 11 MPa under moistureequilibrated condition. The results of excess adsorption of methane are displayed in Fig. 2. Methane adsorption capacity varies significantly in different shale samples with different TOC content. As shown in Fig. 2, methane adsorption capacity of shale samples appreciably increases with the increasing TOC content, indicating the TOC content plays an important role in methane adsorption capacity (Jarvie et al., 2007; Ross and Bustin, 2008; Zhang et al., 2012a,b; Gasparik et al., 2014; Ji et al., 2014, 2015). Under the
es.
measured pressure range, the isotherms of the shale samples increase monotonously with pressure, and subsequently become stable. The experimental methane adsorption isotherms for all shale samples were fitted using the Langmuir adsorption model (Langmuir, 1918). Fairly good fitting results can be observed between calculated and experimentally measured isotherms (Fig. 2). The Langmuir parameters obtained from the least square fit of experimental methane adsorption isotherms are listed in Table 2. The Langmuir volume varies significantly in different shale samples, ranging from 1.54 cm3/g to 3.65 cm3/g and the Langmuir pressures are between 1.50 MPa and 1.57 MPa.

sections.heading: 3.3. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms
sections.text:
The ultra-low pressure nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms data of 11 Longmaxi shale samples at 196 C are illustrated in Fig. 3. The isotherms are reversible at low relative pressures, whereas they show hysteresis loops at higher relative pressures (relative pressure above 0.5). This indicates that capillary condensation occurs in the mesopores (Gregg and Sing, 1982). The adsorption isotherms of shale samples belong to Type IV isotherm (isotherm with hysteresis loop) according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) classification (Sing et al., 1985). And such an isotherm type suggests that shale samples contain bothmesopores andmacropores (Sing et al., 1985). The differentiations between isotherms at relative pressure of 0e0.5 and 0.5e1 are caused by different adsorptionmechanisms. At lower relative pressures the isotherms reflect adsorption behavior dominated by Van der Waals forces, whereas the isotherms at higher relative pressures represent adsorption actions dominated by capillary condensations and evaporations (Sing, 2004; Yao et al., 2008). The shape of the hysteresis loop can be used to understand the morphology of pore shape in solid (Sing et al., 1985). However, the Longmaxi shale samples develop a complex pore systemwhich contains various pore types. This complex pore system results in atypical hysteresis loop curve shapes which cannot be classified as any loop type according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) classification (Sing et al., 1985).
The sequence of decrease in the adsorption amount of N2 for different shale samples is closely related to the TOC content. From Fig. 3, the N2 adsorption amount of shale samples can be found to obviously decrease with the decreasing TOC content in the order: the shale samples with TOC content more than 2% (Fig. 3A) > the shale samples with TOC content between 2% and 1% (Fig. 3B) > the shale samples with TOC content less than 1% (Fig. 3C). This observation reveals that TOC play an important role in the N2 adsorption amount of the Longmaxi marine shales. This is possibly because abundant micro-nanometer scale pores associated with the organic fraction were developed in the shale samples, which can be well
observed on FE-SEM images (Fig. 4). Additionally, the adsorption amount of N2 for the shale samples close to relative pressure 1 is a little higher than conventional low pressure N2 physisorption. Maybe it is because the pores between packing sample particles of 80e100 mesh size were also measured.

sections.heading: 3.4. Pore structure from N2 desorption isotherms
sections.text: Pore structure basically refers to the specific surface area, total pore volume, pore size distribution, and average pore diameter. These parameters can be obtained from N2 adsorption experiment, when applied over a wide range of relative pressures (P/P0). The equivalent surface area was calculated within a relative pressure range of 0.05e0.3 using the multi-point BET equation (Brunauer et al., 1938), and the BET specific surface areas of studied samples range from 10.42 m2/g to 29.93 m2/g, with an average value of 21.32m2/g. These results are similar to othermarine shales in south China such as the Longmaxi shale in western Hunan and Hubei Provinces (Hu et al., 2016), the Upper Ordovician Wufeng Formation shale in the southwest portion of the Sichuan Basin (Xiong et al., 2015) and the Lower Cambrian Niutitang Formation in Sichuan Basin (Yang et al., 2014). BJH pore volumes vary from 0.04157 cm3/g to 0.12970 cm3/g, with a mean value of 0.07706 cm3/ g, and the average pore diameters range from 9.01 nm to 22.54 nm, with an average of 15.81 nm (Table 2). Under ultra-low pressure (10 7~10 2) micropore filling occurs and the N2 molecule can enter micropore (Lowell et al., 2004). In addition, pores between packing sample particles of 80e100 mesh size may also be measured. Thus the pore volumes and the average pore diameters measured in this study are a little larger than that measured from conventional low pressure N2 adsorption analysis (e.g. Hu et al., 2016; Xiong et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2014). These parameters show wide ranges and indicate the complexity of pore morphology and size distribution.

sections.heading: 3.5. Fractal dimensions from N2 desorption isotherms
sections.text:
Fractal concepts were introduced in 1975 (Mandelbrot, 1975) and fractal analysis can be used to characterize the geometric and structural properties of the solid (Pfeifer and Avnir, 1983; Avnir and Jaroniec, 1989). The quantitative evaluation of the fractal geometry is described by using the fractal dimension D, which is used as an index of surface roughness or structural irregularity of the solid (Pfeifer and Avnir, 1983). The fractal dimension can vary from 2 to 3. The lowest value 2 corresponds to a perfectly smooth surface or homogenous pore structure and the upper value 3 corresponds to a totally irregular or rough surface or inhomogeneous pore (Pfeifer and Avnir, 1983; Yao et al., 2008). Based on the N2 adsorption data, the fractal dimension can be determined by the FrenkelHalsey-Hill (FHH) equation (Pfeifer and Avnir, 1983), and the FHH
therms and Langmuir parameters from CH4 adsorption isotherms at 40 C.
model can be described as follows (Avnir and Jaroniec, 1989; Yao et al., 2008).
ln V ¼ ðD 3Þln ln P0 P þ C
where V represents the adsorption volume (cm3/g) at equilibrium pressure P; P0 (MPa) is the vapor saturation pressure;D is the fractal dimension D; C is a constant.
According to the fractal FHH model, on the plot of ln(V) vs ln(ln(P0/P)), the slope of the straight-line should be equal to D-3 (Yao et al., 2008). The FHH plots of 11 Longmaxi shale samples are illustrated in Fig. 5. There are two different linear segments at the P/ P0 ranges of 0e0.5 and 0.5e1, reflecting different gas adsorption mechanisms in these two regions (Yao et al., 2008; Wang et al., 2015b; Bu et al., 2015). The fairly good fitting results (with correlation coefficients of R2 > 0.98, see Fig. 3 and Table 3) indicate
different fractal characteristics at the two intervals (Yao et al., 2008; Bu et al., 2015). Based on these phenomena, the fractal dimensions D1 and D2 were calculated at the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0e0.5 and 0.5e1 using FHH equation. The fitting equations, correlation coefficients of R2 and fractal dimension values (D1 and D2) are summarized in Table 3. The fractal dimension D1 values are relatively low, ranging from 2.3542 to 2.4715, with a mean of 2.4146. The fractal dimension D2 values are from 2.5818 to 2.7497, with an average of 2.6459, indicating high pore structure complexity. These results are consistent with previous studies (Yao et al., 2008; Bu et al., 2015). Based on different adsorption characteristic at different pressure range, Yao et al. (2008) suggested that the fractal dimension D1 at lower relative pressure characterizes the action of Van der Waals forces and reflects the surface fractal dimension. The fractal dimension D2 at higher relative pressure corresponds to the action of capillary condensation and represents the pore structure fractal dimension. The relationships between the
different fractal dimensions and pore structures will be discussed in detail below and to discuss the effects of the different fractal dimensions on methane adsorption properties.

sections.heading: 4. Discussions
sections.text: To study the different effects of fractal dimensions D1 and D2 of the Longmaxi shale on methane adsorption properties, it is necessary to investigate the relationships among fractal dimensions, shale compositions and pore structure parameters.

sections.heading: 4.1. Relationships between fractal dimensions and pore structure parameters
sections.text:
To resolve the role of pore structure of organic shale on fractal characteristics of different shale samples, all correlated relationships between fractal dimensions and pore structure parameters are plotted in Fig. 6A ~ F and the pore structure parameters of the shale samples are summarized in Table 2.
A Slight negative correlation trend (Fig. 6A) and a strongly negative linear relationship with correlation coefficients of R2¼ 0.9455 (Fig. 6B) were found between fraction dimension D1, D2 and the average pore diameter, respectively. These findings are consistent with the findings of coal (Yao et al., 2008), marine gas shale (Yang et al., 2014) and lacustrine shale (Wang et al., 2015b). Both fractal dimensions D1 and D2 increasewith decreasing average pore diameters. Additionally, the correlation of D2 with the average pore diameter is better than that of D1 with the average pore diameter, indicating that D2 may best represent the pore structure fractal dimension and thus, it is more sensitive to the average pore diameter than D1. Shale samples with smaller average pore diameters may also contain more throats and micropores (Yao et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2014), which lead to more heterogonous and complicated pore structure and higher fractal dimension D2 values. These small throats and microspores enhance the pore structure complexity and hinder the natural gas flow in this pore network. Therefore, the Longmaxi shales with higher fraction dimensions are more favor to shale gas accumulation.
Fractal dimensions D1 show a good positive relationship with the BET surface area with a correlation coefficient of R2 ¼ 0.6879 (Fig. 6C), i.e., shale samples with larger fractal dimension D1 always have larger BET surface areas. However, the relationship between fractal dimension D2 and the BET surface area is ambiguous (Fig. 6D), which means surface area has a significant impact on the fractal dimension D1, but not D2. These findings suggest that D1may reflect surface roughness and best represent the surface fractal dimension as discussed before. Higher fractal dimension D1 results in higher surface area in the Longmaxi shale, which can supply more sites for methane adsorption.
There is also a slight positive correlation between fractal dimension D1 and the BJH total pore volume of the shale samples (Fig. 6E). Instead, fractal dimension D1 shows a slight negative linear trend with the BJH total pore volume of the shale samples (Fig. 6F). The differentials between D1 and D2 indicate that pore volume has some different influences on fractal dimensions D1 and D2.

sections.heading: 4.2. Relationships between fractal dimensions and the composition and TOC content of shales
sections.text:
In order to understand the role of mineralogical compositions and TOC content of the Longmaxi shale samples on fractal characteristics, all correlated relationships between fractal dimensions and mineralogical compositions, TOC content are plotted in Fig. 7. The fractal dimensions of the Longmaxi shale samples reflect that the nano-pores in the Longmaxi shale samples have irregular surface and heterogeneous pore space morphology. As shown in Fig. 7, D1 and D2 illustrate different relationships with other parameters, for example, TOC, brittle mineral content and clay mineral content.
Both fractal dimension D1 and D2 have slight positive linear correlation relationships with TOC content (Fig. 7A and B). Shale samples with higher TOC content will have greater fractal dimensions. This is consistent with marine shale from the Lower Cambrian Niutitang Formation (Yang et al., 2014) and lacustrine shale from the Upper Triassic Yanchang Formation (Liu et al., 2015). As shown in Fig. 4, a numerous complicated nano-pore network
B), BET surface area (C, D) and BJH pore volume (E, F) of Longmaxi shale.
could be formed in the organic matter during thermal maturation, hence, the higher TOC content is, the more complicated and heterogeneous pore structure of shales would be. Additionally, shales with higher TOC content have more micropores (Ross and Bustin, 2009; Loucks et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2014; Ji et al., 2014, 2015), leading to more complex pore structure, and consequently resulting in larger fractal dimensions (Liu et al., 2015). Therefore, the higher TOC content in shale may lead tomoremicropores andmore complicated pore structure, and in turn result in greater fractal dimensions D1 and D2.
Fractal dimensions D1 and D2 have opposite linear relationship with clayminerals content and brittle minerals content (Fig. 7C and D). The fractal dimension D1 shows aweak positive correlationwith increasing clay minerals content (Fig. 7C). This may be caused by the complex crystal structure of clay minerals. Whereas the fractal dimension D2 is negatively correlated with clay minerals content (Fig. 7D), probably because shale samples with higher clay content contain more adsorbed water. The pores may be more homogeneous as a result of pore filling by water molecules (Yao et al., 2008). Accordingly, shale sample with high clay content may have a greater fractal dimension D1 and a less fractal dimension D2.
There exists a slight negative linear relationship between fractal dimension D1 and brittle minerals content, indicating the brittle minerals have a little effect on fractal dimension D1. This is possibly due to the fact that the surface of brittle mineral grain is smoother and more homogenous than organic matter and clay minerals. In contrast, there appears to exist a significant binomial correlation (R2 ¼ 0.4068) between fractal dimension D2 and brittle minerals content. Fractal dimension D2 decreases with increasing brittle minerals content up to about 50% and thereafter increases with increasing brittle minerals content (Fig. 7F). This may be caused by the better protection of complex organic pore network from numerous brittle mineral grains, which results in a greater fractal dimension D2.

sections.heading: 4.3. Effects of shale composition and TOC content on pore structure
sections.text:
Fractal dimension is an index of surface roughness or structural
irregularity of solid, which reflects the geometric and structural properties of solid (Pfeifer and Avnir, 1983). Obviously, the pore structure of the Longmaxi shale may be the core control upon fractal dimension. Themineralogical compositions and TOC of shale impact on the pore structure, which in turn exert influences on fractal dimension as discussed in 4.2. Thus the relationships between pore structures and shale composition were plotted in Fig. 8 to discuss the effects of shale composition and TOC content on pore structures. As shown in Fig. 8AeC, the average pore diameters of the Longmaxi shale samples have a slight negative linear trendwith TOC content and brittle mineral content and a weak positive relationship with clay mineral content. Shale samples with higher TOC content have smaller average pore diameter, which may be due to organic matter have more micropores compared to mineralogical compositions. Additionally, at higher TOC levels, the organic matter pores may collapse due to the relative weakened protection from mineral grains, thus producing more complex smaller pores (Wang et al., 2015b).
The BET surface areas show a good positive correlation with TOC content with a correlation coefficient of R2 ¼ 0.615 (Fig. 8D), but not obvious relationship with clay mineral content and brittle mineral content (Fig. 8E and F). These relationships indicate organic matter in shale is the major contributor to the surface area. Similarly, there exists a positive linear trend between the BJH pore volume and TOC content, except sample YC4-2 with TOC content of 4.13% (see red dashed circle in Fig. 8G). The BJH pore volume shows a positive linear trend with clay mineral content (Fig. 8H) and a negative linear trend with brittle mineral content (Fig. 8I). These relationships indicate that organic pores and intercrystalline pores and intraplatelet pores within clay minerals provide the large amount of pore volume in shale samples. The abnormal sample YC4-2 with a high TOC content of 4.13% (see red dashed circle in Fig. 8G) have a low pore volume, which may most likely result from organic matter pores collapse in shale with high TOC content. This can be well manifested by the negative relationship between average pore diameters and TOC content in Fig. 8A.

sections.heading: 4.4. Relationships between fractal dimension and Langmuir parameters of CH4 adsorption
sections.text:
Methane adsorption characteristics of shale are controlled by many geological factors such as organic matter properties (type, abundance, and maturity), composition of inorganic minerals (especially clay minerals), micro and nano pore structures, moisture content, and pressure and temperature regimes (e.g. Jarvie et al., 2007; Ross and Bustin, 2008; Zhang et al., 2012a,b; Rexer et al., 2013; Gasparik et al., 2014; Ji et al., 2014, 2015). However, the impacts of fractal dimensions of pores on methane adsorption of shales were rarely investigated. Here we discuss the relationships between fractal dimensions and Langmuir volume (VL) and Langmuir pressure (PL) of methane adsorption in the Longmaxi shale. The parameter Langmuir volume (VL) represents the maximum gas adsorption capacity at a constant temperature, which determines the gas adsorption capacity: higher methane adsorption capacity is associated with higher Langmuir volume (VL). The Langmuir pressure (PL, in MPa), which is the reciprocal of the Langmuir constant, represents the pressure at which the amount of adsorbed gas equals one-half of the maximum gas adsorption capacity. And the Langmuir constant is the ratio of adsorption rate to desorption rate. Therefore the larger Langmuir pressure constant reflects lower adsorption rate and higher desorption rate.
As shown in Fig. 9A and B, the Langmuir volumes of shale samples have slight positive linear trends with both fractal dimensions D1 and D2. The observed trends are in agreement with previous study (Yang et al., 2014). Higher fractal dimension D1 and D2 values represent more rough surfaces and higher heterogeneity of pore structures of shales that offer more adsorption sites for methane and thus can lead to higher adsorption capacity of shales. Therefore, the fractal dimension may act as a good budget for shale gas adsorption capacity evaluation.
The Langmuir pressures of shale samples have a negative relationshipwith fractal dimensions D1, but a positive relationshipwith fractal dimensions D2. Shales with higher D1 values have more rough surfaces which result in higher adsorption energy because of the overlapping of the adsorption potential energy in the opposite pore walls (Wang et al., 2015a). Therefore, shales with higher D1 values have lower desorption rates and lower Langmuir pressures. Shales with higher D2 values would have more throats or more complicated pore structure, which increase the tortuosity and decrease the connection of the pore network. These make the gas flow and diffuse in the pore network much tougher, in turn, results in lower adsorption rates and larger Langmuir pressures. The larger Langmuir pressures make methane desorption in shale reservoir easier to achieve, which facilitate the production of shale gas. Fractal dimensions are therefore significant in the context of the Longmaxi shale gas exploitation.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this paper, the FHH theory has been applied to investigate the fractal characteristics of the nano-pores in the Lower Silurian Longmaxi marine shale from the Upper Yangtze Platform in south China using nitrogen adsorption analyses. The relationships between TOC content, minerals content, pore structure parameters and fractal dimensions have been investigated. Furthermore, based on the physical significance of fractal dimensions, the effect of fractal dimensions on the methane adsorption in shales has also been discussed. The following conclusions have been obtained.
(1) The Longmaxi marine shale samples have different adsorption characteristics of N2 at relative pressure ranges of 0e0.5 and 0.5e1. On this basis, two fractal dimensions D1 and D2 corresponding to relative pressures of 0e0.5 and 0.5e1, respectively were obtained by using the fractal FHH method, with D1 ranging from 2.3542 to 2.471, and D2 ranging from 2.5818 to 2.7497. (2) The fractal dimension D1 shows a good positive correlation with the BET surface area, suggesting that D1 may represent the surface fractal dimension. Fractal dimension D2 shows a strongly negative linear relationship with the average pore diameter, indicating that D2 may comparatively have more to do with the pore structure fractal dimension. (3) The organic matter has a positive influence on the BET surface area and the BJH pore volume, and a negative effect on average pore diameter. The BJH pore volume and the average pore diameter have a positive relationship trend with clay minerals contents, but a negative linear trendwith the brittle minerals content. The mineralogical compositions and TOC of the Longmaxi shales have different impacts on the pore structure parameters, which in turn exert different effects on the fractal dimensions D1 and D2. (4) Shale sample with a higher fractal dimension has greater adsorption capacity. A higher fractal dimension indicates
that the shale sample has amore irregular surface and higher heterogeneity of pore structures, which provides a greater surface area for methane adsorption. The fractal dimensions D1 and D2 have different effects on the Langmuir pressures of shale samples. The Langmuir pressures have a negative relationship with the fractal dimension D1 and a positive relationship with the fractal dimension D2. Taken as a whole, the high fractal dimension D1 increase methane adsorption capacity and favor shale gas accumulation in the Longmaxi formation and the high fractal dimension D2 facilitate the gas production from shale reservoirs.

metadata.abstractText: To better understand the fractal characteristics of nano-pore structure and their effects on methane adsorption in marine shales, we have conducted ultra-low pressure nitrogen adsorption, methane adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), total organic carbon (TOC), and vitrinite reflectance for eleven shale samples of the Lower Silurian Longmaxi Formation from the Upper Yangtze Platform, south China. Two fractal dimensions D1 and D2 (at relative pressures of 0e0.5 and 0.5e1, respectively) were obtained using the fractal FrenkeleHalseyeHill (FHH) method based on low-pressure nitrogen adsorption isotherms. The relationships among composition of the Longmaxi shale (TOC, clay minerals, brittle minerals), the pore structure parameters (i.e. average pore diameter, surface area, pore volume), and the fractal dimensions were investigated. The results show that the Longmaxi shale possesses fractal geometries with fractal dimension D1 values ranging from 2.3542 to 2.4715 and fractal dimension D2 values ranging from 2.5818 to 2.7497. The good positive correlation between fractal dimensions D1 and the BET surface area and the strongly negative relationship between fractal dimensions D2 and the average pore diameter indicate that D1 can adequately characterize pore surface fractal dimension, while D2 represents the pore structure fractal dimension. Organic matter has a positive influence on the BET surface area and the BJH pore volume and a negative effect on the average pore diameter. The BJH pore volume and the average pore diameter have a positive relationship trend with the clay minerals content, whereas a negative linear trend with the brittle minerals content. The mineralogical compositions and TOC of the Longmaxi shale have different impacts on the pore structures, which in turn exert different effects on the fractal dimensions D1 and D2. Both the fractal dimensions D1 and D2 have positive effects on the Langmuir volume of methane adsorption. However, the fractal dimensions D1 and D2 have opposite influence on the Langmuir pressures of methane adsorption. Thus the fractal dimensions can well be used to evaluate gas shale reservoir and shale gas accumulation in south China. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
